message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Prader-Willi syndrome, and among the options, only methylation of maternal chromosome 15 is associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Prader-Willi Syndrome, which is caused by abnormalities on chromosome 15. Specifically, it is caused by the loss of function of genes from the paternal chromosome 15 or the methylation of the maternal chromosome 15. Option A is associated with Williams syndrome, option B is associated with Marfan syndrome, and option C is associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described, including central obesity and almond-shaped eyes, suggest a diagnosis of Prader-Willi syndrome. This is caused by the lack of expression of paternal genes on chromosome 15. Methylation of maternal chromosome 15 is one of the genetic changes associated with this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the behavioral problems, central obesity, and undescended testes, suggest Prader-Willi syndrome. Among the options, only Methylation of maternal chromosome 15 is associated with this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Prader-Willi syndrome, and among the options, only methylation of the maternal chromosome 15 is associated with this condition. Microdeletion of long arm of chromosome 7 is associated with Williams syndrome, mutation of FBN-1 gene on chromosome 15 is associated with Marfan syndrome, and deletion of Phe508 on maternal chromosome 7 is associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the central obesity and hunger, suggest Prader-Willi syndrome, which is caused by the lack of expression of genes on the paternal chromosome 15. Methylation of the maternal chromosome 15 is the most likely genetic change associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including behavioral problems, frequent hunger, and central obesity, suggest Prader-Willi syndrome, which is caused by loss of function or expression in genes on the paternal chromosome 15. Methylation of the maternal chromosome 15 can also result in loss of function. Microdeletion of long arm of chromosome 7 is associated with Williams syndrome, which has different symptoms. Mutation of FBN-1 gene on chromosome 15 is associated with Marfan syndrome. Deletion of Phe508 on maternal chromosome 7 is associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has Prader-Willi Syndrome, which is caused by a deletion or uniparental disomy of the paternal chromosome 15 or a methylation defect of the maternal chromosome 15. Among the options, only (D) Methylation of maternal chromosome 15 is associated with Prader-Willi Syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Prader-Willi syndrome, which is caused by loss of function of paternal genes on chromosome 15. There are two types of Prader-Willi syndrome, one caused by a microdeletion of the paternal chromosome 15, and the other by methylation of the maternal chromosome 15. Methylation of maternal chromosome 15 is the more common cause, making (D) the correct answer. The other options are not associated with Prader-Willi syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome, which is caused by a lack of expression of paternally inherited genes on chromosome 15. This can occur due to uniparental disomy, deletion of the maternal chromosome, or imprinting error. Methylation of maternal chromosome 15 is the most common cause of Prader-Willi syndrome. The other options are associated with Williams syndrome, Marfan syndrome, and cystic fibrosis respectively.
